title: 111_hr5354
content: The Act titled "Gestational Diabetes Act of 2010" or "GEDI Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on gestational diabetes. The GEDI Act of 2010 amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on gestational diabetes. The Act mandates the development of a multisite gestational diabetes research project to enhance surveillance data and public health research on gestational diabetes. This project will focus on establishing accurate data collection systems within each State and commonwealth. The GEDI Act of 2010 mandates the development of a multisite gestational diabetes research project to improve surveillance data on gestational diabetes. This includes tracking women postpartum, implementing interventions to lower the incidence of type 2 diabetes, and studying variations in diagnosed and undiagnosed gestational diabetes. The GEDI Act of 2010 requires a research project on gestational diabetes to study factors influencing risks, interventions to reduce complications, and generate annual reports on prevalence. The Secretary is mandated to expand public health research on gestational diabetes, including developing new approaches for postpartum diabetes testing and preventing type 2 diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes. Additionally, research will focus on understanding factors influencing the risk of gestational diabetes and type 2 diabetes development in these women. Authorization of $5,000,000 annually from 2012 to 2016 for grants to lower gestational diabetes rates. Grants prioritize projects reducing gestational diabetes incidence, recurrence, and type 2 diabetes development in women with a history of gestational diabetes. The Secretary shall prioritize projects focusing on helping women at risk for gestational diabetes, providing postpartum care, tracking cases of type 2 diabetes, educating mothers about diabetes risks, and preventing gestational diabetes and type 2 diabetes development in women with a history of gestational diabetes. The Secretary prioritizes projects to help women at risk for gestational diabetes, provide postpartum care, track type 2 diabetes cases, educate mothers about diabetes risks, and prevent gestational diabetes and type 2 diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes. Eligible entities seeking grants must submit an application and a plan to lower gestational diabetes rates or track women with a history of the condition. The eligible entities receiving grants will use the funds for demonstration projects aimed at preventing gestational diabetes and type 2 diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes. This includes expanding community-based health promotion activities and aiding state- and tribal-based diabetes prevention programs. The prevention and control programs aim to collect, analyze, disseminate, and report surveillance data on women at risk for gestational diabetes, its recurrence in subsequent pregnancies, and the development of type 2 diabetes. Health care providers are trained to promote risk assessment, high-quality care, and self-management for gestational diabetes and prevent type 2 diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the results of demonstration projects related to diabetes in women with a history of gestational diabetes. Eligible entities include nonprofit organizations and state, tribal, or local health agencies. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2012 through 2016. The Secretary will work with diabetes prevention programs to encourage postpartum follow-up after gestational diabetes to reduce its incidence and related complications. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on September 30, 2010, as attested by Clerk Lorraine C. Miller.
